name: 6Intro
_source: # WAGON TIME WAGON TIME YES THE WAGON THE WAGON
speak;Marcel;You idiot driver!{w}{clear}Stay on the road!
speak;James;I'm sure you've realized this, Madeline,{w} but Marcel is actually a woman.
speak;James;She works as a waitress in a restaurant in the red-light district at night.
speak;James;She goes by the stage-name of Rachel.
speak;Madeline;Marcel, does this mean I'm a lesbian?
speak;James;Take your clothes off then,{w} if you've got nothing to hide.
speak;Marcel;Look closely, Madeline,{w} on the bump on his head.{w}{clear}Undeniable proof.

speak;Bella;...Stuck in a place that was not quite Heaven.{w}{clear}Stuck in a place that was not quite Hell.{w}{clear}The Phoenix cried and cried,{w} stuck in a place it could never escape.{w} Eventually,{w} it fell to sleep,{w} in sleep,{w} began to dream. It dreamt of a world,{w} a heavenly world,{w} a world like Heaven,{w} yet not quite Heaven,{w} and certainly not like Hell.{w}{clear}A world of friendship and peace and hope and love and people.{w}{clear}People like you,{w} and people like me.{w}{clear}These people were different from the people the Phoenix knew.{w}{clear}Not quite Gods.{w}{clear}But not quite devils either.{w}{clear}They spoke in a tongue that in turn spoke in tongues,{w} which in turn spoke the words of a language.{w} A language of dreams,{w} that spoke of dreams -{w} of dreams with their own desires....
speak;Alice;Anthony, is your axe a Conceptual Weapon?
speak;Anthony;Have you asked Marcel the same question?
speak;Anthony;And so, by asking me,{w} you thought you could get an idea of what he believes in.{w}{clear} Am I wrong?
speak;Anthony;Do you want to know if I know?
speak;Anthony;Alright, I’ll tell you,{w} even though I shouldn’t,{w} considering he hasn’t.

speak;Anthony;Our mother was a very kind woman.{w}{clear}She spent a lot of time with Marcel and I.{w}{clear}Marcel especially.{w}{clear}He was born in a sickly sort of coma,{w} so she had a habit of taking care of him that persisted,{w} into the later years of his childhood.{w}{clear}Father called him spoilt,{w} and coddled,{w} and said she had ruined him,{w} and I mimicked Father in a joking sort of way.{w}{clear}But I think we were both jealous of the attention she gave him.{w}{clear}I know it is absurd to think of the king being capable of human emotion,{w} but he is.{w}{clear}The realization came to me one day -{w} I was back in from training,{w} in a wagon like this one,{w} when a man from the castle jumped in on the way.{w}{clear}He spoke in an offhand sort of way,{w} like you normally would to a stranger,{w} saying that the queen had passed away.{w}{clear}He looked at me then and saw who I was.{w}{clear}I asked him to repeat what he said.{w}{clear}I would’ve asked him again but he jumped out at the first opportunity.{w}{clear}Despite being told twice,{w} for days,{w} it didn’t quite settle in.{w}{clear}Maybe instead of saying "passed away" -{w} if the passenger said she was dead,{w} the message might have set in sooner.{w}{clear}Maybe if his manner was more sombre and serious, I would’ve reacted in the appropriate manner.{w}{clear}I -

speak;Anthony;Though I was sixteen,{w} I was strong enough to carry the coffin,{w} at the funeral.{w}{clear}I volunteered.{w}{clear}Marcel was eleven,{w} he wasn’t there,{w} he was in bed with a fever.{w}{clear}My father and I were left alone to watch the burial.{w}{clear}I remember that I thought that the dirt was making a strange noise when it hit the lid of the coffin,{w}{clear}then I noticed that the thuds of earth weren't quite matching up with the noise,{w}{clear}then I turned to my father,{w} to see him there crying,{w} and only then did I truly understand.

speak;Anthony;It was like my head was encased in ice.{w}{clear}And it was bad for Marcel.{w}{clear}You can’t understand, at that age -{w} or rather, you can’t trick yourself into understanding -{w} that people die for no reason.{w}{clear}He looked around for a culprit,{w} someone to blame,{w}to take out the sense of frustration at the helplessness of his situation,{w} saw no one to blame,{w} turned the frustration inward,{w} and blamed himself.{w}{clear} He said to me that what happened was the natural and just reward of a family of soldiers trained to kill others,{w}{clear}that we could not kill others and get away with it ourselves,{w}{clear}that the universe itself had intervened to balance out the scales.{w}{clear}Marcel has bared the cross of this belief ever since.
# Outside, the wagon is stopped. Elizabeth files in. show her portrait!!
speak;Claudia;Why are we chasing them on foot.
speak;Claude;Not the most genius of strategies, I'll admit.
speak;Claudia;I told you we should've waited to get help back at town.
speak;Claudia;How on earth out of a sea of options did you pick the absolute worst possible one?
speak;Claude;Easy to say when you don't make any decisions yourself.
speak;Claudia;You don't let me make any.
speak;Anthony;Are you lost by any chance?
speak;Anthony;So that must be Claudia behind you there.
speak;Claudia;Actually, we want to ask you a favour.{w}{clear}Can we ride in your wagons and catch up to them?
speak;Marcel;How long have you been travelling for?
speak;Claudia;We didn't have time to sleep.{w}{clear}Claude didn't get any at all.
# James steps out, as well as a few others
speak;Marcel;James, can you take care of these two?{w}{clear}I think it's just exhaustion, mostly,{w} and dehydration.
speak;Elizabeth;Sir.{w}{clear}There's a cavalry regiment approaching up the road.
speak;Marcel;How could they mount a response so quickly?
speak;Anthony;He must've sent a message for reinforcements prior to the battle at Wolfstock.
speak;Anthony;We've no choice.{w}{clear}Most of our troops are resting though.
speak;SoldierRed;Sir!{w}{clear}Shouldn't we wait for the remaining cavalry regiments to arrive before mounting an attack?

speak;Dempsey;Fintan has deliberately positioned us in such a way.{w}{clear}He wants to claim the glory for capturing Marcel.{w}{clear}We'll get no credit if we stand around.{w}{clear}Do you want to fight for nothing?
# battle preps - James, Claude, Claudia unavailable
